words.source: The Tempest -- a Latin word that meant "to abstain from alcoholic drink" was generalized to sexual behavior as well
Love's Labour's Lost; this is just an English form of "Academy", the Greek for Plato's grove
Romeo and Juliet; Spanish "aligarto" was already in use in English
13 instances; first known use as a noun
I Henry IV; first attestation in English of the Spanish word for dried edible fish
Measure for Measure / Timon of Athens
2 Henry VI / Hamlet; "rouse" was the usual form
Macbeth; "assassin" was already in use and derives from "hashish eater"
several; "auspice" was a Roman practice of fortune-telling by bird flight
I Henry VI; this is just a pun on a known word
II Henry VI, actually "bandetto", the first attestation in English of a familiar Italian word for people "banned", i.e., outlaws
in the sense of fantasy without grounding in fact
A Midsummer Night's Dream, merely means a place to sleep on the ground
King Lear; first use as a verb
Romeo and Juliet; first attestation of onomopoeic word
Timon of Athens, first attestation as a verb
As You Like It; from coetous,a buyer of provisions
Macbeth; first attestation as a verb, and in an older sense of "to challenge"; though the noun was familiar as someone who would fight for another
As You Like It / Cymbeline; first attestation in the sense of "indirect"
King John; first use to mean "lack of emotion"
several; seems to have been a common word
The Merchant of Venice, several of the histories; seems to have been already in use
Macbeth; first use in English of a Scandinavian verb
Twelfth Night; "consanguinity" was already in use
I Henry IV, King John; first use as a noun, the standard had been "dawning"
several, must have been a common expression
II Henry IV; in the sense of a noise that is loud but does not produce real deafness
several; already a word in Latin
Richard III / Titus Andronicus; the verb was in use but this is the first attestation as a noun
Hamlet / Measure for Measure; seems possible
Henry V / King Lear; probably already in use as referring to a royal title
Love's Labour's Lost; from a Dutch word

Macbeth; first use as a verb

King Lear; first use as a verb
I Henry VI; first use as a noun
several, seems simply the first attestation
King Lear; first use as an adjective, though the noun was old
Othello / All's Well that Ends Well; first use as adjective, though the verb "to equivocate" was familiar
Hamlet / Troilus and Cressida; both times as plural; first use as a noun
several, supposedly first use as noun

The Merry Wives of Windsor; first known use of the compound
Timon of Athens / Troilus and Cressida
King Lear; first use as an adjective

several; "frugality" was already in common use
several; the word had originally meant red-and-warm
Measure for Measure; alteration of knurled which was a standard word for bumpy

III Henry VI, seems already familiar and was an Old Norse word
Othello, first use in today's sense

Twelfth Night; older term was "hab, nab", and not in today's sense
several, seems like a word that is already familiar

The Taming of the Shrew; seems unlikely

several, and not used in the modern sense
King Lear, first attestation as a noun

II Henry IV, not in present sense
The Merry Wives of Windsor; signifies "flirting"

words.word: invulnerable King John / Hamlet / The Tempest; first attestation for the negative; Coriolanus has unvulnerable)
